subject: Re: [junit] Multiple assertions per test
msgSnippet: Is there any situation in which multiple assertions per test can be justified? For example, talking to an expensive external resource that can t easily be
messageBody:
Is there any situation in which multiple assertions per test can be
justified? For example, talking to an expensive external resource that
can't easily be mocked (e.g. third party hardware)?
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chaudhary, Harsh wrote:
>
>> Is there a way in jUnit to override the failfast behavior e.g. my code
>> looks like:
>>
>> public void testOrder() {
>>
>> assertEquals(9, Largest.largest(new int[] {9,8,7}));
>>
>> assertEquals(44, Largest.largest(new int[] {8,9,7}));
>>
>> assertEquals(32, Largest.largest(new int[] {7,8,9}));
>>
>> }
>>
>> I know the 2nd and 3rd asserts would fail. I want to see both results as
>> having failed in my results. But jUnit just stops at the first failure.
>>
>> Is there any way to change this behavior?
>
> This is a FAQ. Google "JUnit multiple assertions per test". I explain
> the reasons why JUnit isn't built this way in _JUnit Recipes_ and a
> number of us have re-written that answer dozens of times in this mailing
> list, so check the archives.
>
> The short version: No, you can't, and you shouldn't, because those are 3
> different tests.
>
> For the longer version, search the web.
>
> Take care.
